attributes.Title: Gen Chem-Sci
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Chemistry
111
UMass Amherst
Basic principles of structure and reactivity. Microscopic nature of atoms and molecules; the macroscopic properties of chemical systems. Topics include stoichiometry, thermochemistry, atomic structure, molecular structure, properties of gases. (Gen.Ed. PS)
 
Prerequisites: MATH 101 and MATH 102, or its equivalent of  MATH 104, or a score of 20 or higher on Part "A" of the Math Placement test, or MATH 127, 128, 131, or 132.  Note: a maximum of 5 units may be received for both CHEM 101 and CHEM 102, or 2 units for either, if CHEM 111 is completed.
Math placemnt, 104, 127, 128,
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
64061
Requisite: Prerequisites: MATH 101 and MATH 102, or its equivalent of  MATH 104, or a score of 20 or higher on Part "A" of the Math Placement test, or MATH 127, 128, 131, or 132.  Note: a maximum of 5 units may be received for both CHEM 101 and CHEM 102, or 2 units for either, if CHEM 111 is completed.

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
490W
UMass Amherst
This course will cover topics in wildlife reproduction and conservation including reproductive cycles in wild animals, reproductive technologies, pharmacological and physical restraint; stress and capture-related death; safety and first aid in the field, and capture methods and transport.
Open to Seniors, Juniors & Sophomores only.

attributes.Title: Intro Biotechnology Laboratory
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
385
UMass Amherst
An introduction to the methodology fundamental to the practice of modern agricultural biotechnology. Techniques covered include establishment and manipulation of plant and animal cell cultures, preparation and analysis of DNA and RNA, production of recombinant protein expression vectors, isolation and characterization of proteins, and use of immunoassays. Major emphasis on the student's performance of laboratory exercises which provide direct experience with each of the techniques mentioned. Prerequisites: BIOLOGY 101 and CHEM 112, or Consent of Instructor.
PreReq:Biology101,190H,or197FH  Meets with MICROBIO 385
Additional fees are associated with this section.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
64623
63707
Requisite: An introduction to the methodology fundamental to the practice of modern agricultural biotechnology. Techniques covered include establishment and manipulation of plant and animal cell cultures, preparation and analysis of DNA and RNA, production of recombinant protein expression vectors, isolation and characterization of proteins, and use of immunoassays. Major emphasis on the student's performance of laboratory exercises which provide direct experience with each of the techniques mentioned. Prerequisites: BIOLOGY 101 and CHEM 112, or Consent of Instructor.

attributes.Title: Ideas That Change the World
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Honors College
201
UMass Amherst
In this seminar, students will examine texts and works of art that have profoundly shaped the world we live in. The course is divided into four units: Models of Inquiry; the Impact of Science and Technology; Social Philosophy and Civic Engagement; and Art in the World. The course is supplemented with several plenary lectures by distinguished honors faculty speakers.
This course is open to Commonwealth Honors College students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

Spring
2016
Animal Science
491C

In addition to assisting with research under the direction of your Faculty Sponsor, students will be expected to attend three one hour seminars with instructor of record to receive instruction in research methodologies.
Identify a lab to work in, meet with Faculty sponsor to discuss research expectations and complete Biotech Research contract. Forward completed Biotech Research contract to mschneider@vasci.umass.edu
Students will be responsible for presenting a poster detailing their work by posting it on Science Day at the end of the spring semester. Oral presentation in lab optional.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.

attributes.Title: JournalClub in Cells,Genes&Dev
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
795A
UMass Amherst
The focus is on presentation of manuscripts highlighting innovative discoveries and technical approaches as well as controversial results that address topics related to development and disease. The topics detail contemporary use of genetically engineered organisms to define cell signaling required to establish cell lineages in developing tissues, the process of gametogenesis and epigenetic imprinting and how these mechanisms are disrupted in diseases such as cancer.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63690

attributes.Title: Prac-Small Animal Management
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Animal Science
298C
UMass Amherst
This course is designed to provide students with the basic skills and concepts involved with the proper care and management of companion animals. The class will be comprised of a combination of lectures, laboratory activities, case studies and student presentations.
Open to students in Animal Science Majors Knowlton RAP only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.
29195

attributes.Title: Equine Reproduction
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
445A
UMass Amherst
Horse breeding will provide understanding and hands-on opportunity in equine reproduction. Specifically, semen collection, evaluation and processing practice; discussion in mare breeding management and use of hormones; preparation of the mare for breeding; introduction to embryo transfer. Additionally, the mares in the breeding program at the Hadley Farm will be worked-on during laboratories and students will be able to participate in teasing and decision-making on breeding management and assisting in foaling. Client based cases may also be introduced during lab sessions.
Pre Req: ANIMLSCI 220  Students must have some horse experience and/or knowledge of anatomy and physiology, and be able to get to Hadley Farm for some classes. Students must be committed to and understand the responsibility and effort put into this course to complete it.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63721

attributes.Title: Problem-BasedLrng/AdvAnimlHlth
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Animal Science
390L
UMass Amherst
Real-world cases involving management and veterinary medicine for large animals, companion animals, and wildlife will be presented. With instructor guidance, students will work to identify and solve problems posed by each case, while expanding their knowledge and developing skills in critical thinking, self-directed learning, problem solving, written and oral presentation, and teamwork.
This course is open to BS-Animal Science & BS-Pre-Veterinary Science majors only. ANIMLSCI103,200,220,311,372
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: ST-Livestock Classic
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
297L
UMass Amherst
The grooming and showing of cattle, sheep and goats are taught through hands-on experience and presentation of the animals in a show organized by the students each spring.  The show is open to the public and is held at the Hadley Farm. Previous experience preferred.
This course is open to BS-Animal Science & BS-Pre-Veterinary Science majors only.   Class meets one evening every other week.  Students arrange mutually convenient times to meet with coaches to learn grooming and showing techniques.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63703

attributes.Title: Basic Animal Nutrition&Feeding
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Animal Science
332
UMass Amherst
Detailed study of macro and micro nutrients, their digestion, absorption, and metabolism by various domesticated animal species for maintenance and production. Introduction to feeding programs. 
Prerequisite: ANIMLSCI 103 or 220 or by permission of instructor.
Pre Req: ANIMLSCI 220  An optional honors colloquium, AnimlSci 391H is available for this course. Open to  BS-AnSci and BS-PreVeterinary majors only.
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
390C
UMass Amherst
The purpose of this course is to develop an understanding of the various business management decisions involved in the organization and operation of an animal-related firm for continuous profit and production efficiency. Students will acquire knowledge and proficiency in applying the various economic principles and business management analysis concepts which aid an owner/operator in the decision-making process for an animal-related business operation. Prereq: ANIMLSCI 103 or permission of instructor.
This course is open to BS-Animal Science & BS-Pre-Veterinary Science majors only. Pre Req: ANIMLSCI 103  Open to Junior and Senior BS-AnimlSci and BS-PreVet majors only.

2016

Application to enroll/foster/train a service dog must be made to Sarah Meikle, Director, Diggity Dogs Service Dogs  (Email: sarah@indogswetrust.org; Website: indogswetrust.org). Students must provide their own transportation to Shelburne Falls.
Weekly training logs and classes, monthly progress reports, weekly two-hour classroom training and monthly individual classroom assessments at the training facility in Shelburne Falls, MA are required.

attributes.Title: Introduction to Animal Science
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Animal Science
101
UMass Amherst
With lab. Modern animal agriculture and the many scientific disciplines it encompasses. The roles of genetics, nutrition, economics, physiology, and pathology in animal research and production. The dairy, meat, recreational, and laboratory animal industries in their role serving humankind. Lab experience working with various animal species.
Open to ANIMLSCI majors only.
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Integrating Learning &Research
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
494TI
UMass Amherst
Students will reflect on their General Education experiences and discuss how they directly impact their Honors Thesis. They will share these reflections and discuss how working in a laboratory has impacted their overall educational experience in-class. The students will then work together to co-organize (with the instructor) an information evening that is designed to bring together other VASCI students who are interested in joining laboratories and share their reflections on this topic. At the end of the semester the students will write a formal 5-page reflection piece that will culminate the reflection segment. In addition to co-organizing the information session, the students will also work in groups to debate case-studies on ethics in the laboratory and the morality of stem cell research. Finally the seminar course culminates with several classes devoted to effective presentations and peer-driven critiques of scientific presentations on their original research.  Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BS-AnSci majors.  Pre-requisite: AnimlSci 499Y.  Co-requisite: AnimlSci 499T.
This class is open to Seniors whose Primary majors are in Animal Science or Pre-Veterinary Science only. PreReq: ANIMLSCI 499Y  Students must also be enrolled in ANIMLSCI 499T in order to participate in this class.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63719
Requisite: Students will reflect on their General Education experiences and discuss how they directly impact their Honors Thesis. They will share these reflections and discuss how working in a laboratory has impacted their overall educational experience in-class. The students will then work together to co-organize (with the instructor) an information evening that is designed to bring together other VASCI students who are interested in joining laboratories and share their reflections on this topic. At the end of the semester the students will write a formal 5-page reflection piece that will culminate the reflection segment. In addition to co-organizing the information session, the students will also work in groups to debate case-studies on ethics in the laboratory and the morality of stem cell research. Finally the seminar course culminates with several classes devoted to effective presentations and peer-driven critiques of scientific presentations on their original research.  Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BS-AnSci majors.  Pre-requisite: AnimlSci 499Y.  Co-requisite: AnimlSci 499T.

attributes.Title: Animal Cell & Molecular Biolgy
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
200
UMass Amherst
This course is evenly divided between molecular and cellular aspects of the biology of eukaryotes and is designed to prepare sophomores for upper level science courses such as genetics, biochemistry, immunology, and the physiology of reproduction. Topics covered include DNA packaging and X-inactivation, enzymes and DNA replication, genes and genomes, polymerase chain reaction and forensics, protein structure, cellular structure and signaling, the extracellular matrix, and cell division and death. Problem sets will be based on the analysis of primary scientific journal articles.
BIO151/190H,CHEM111/121H,ANSCI
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63702

attributes.Title: Honors Colloq ANIMLSCI 200
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Animal Science
H200
UMass Amherst
ANIMLSCI H200 covers introductory molecular and cell biology topics. In the honors colloquium for this course, scientific articles are discussed in small groups and methods described in class are demonstrated in a laboratory setting. Students will gain hands-on experience with molecular methods such as PCR amplification of genomic DNA and interpretation of the resulting sequences. We also demonstrate protein purification, and analysis using gel electrophoresis and western blots. Cell culture and live cell imaging using transfection of membrane-GFP and Nuclear-mCherry, will be used to follow cell behavior, compartments and traficking. Each year a different topic may be selected to demonstrate how techniques are used to answer specific scientific questions. In parallel, the group analysis of scientific articles addressing the context of the scientific questions allows the students to develop critical reading, communication and thinking skills.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
29168

attributes.Title: ST-Immunology Journal Club
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Microbiology
797J
UMass Amherst
Critical review of the scientific literature is an integral part of scientific research, and both students and faculty benefit greatly from the discussions originating from these reviews. Each student presents a paper, having made their own selection from top-ranking journals in Immunology.  In most semesters, papers are presented from any area of immunology. In some semesters, the faculty restricts the papers presented to a specific topic. During recent years, such topics were programmed cell death, virus immunology, and receptor-mediated signaling.  Cynthia L. Baldwin, Samuel J. Black, Richard A. Goldsby, Barbara A. Osborne, Janice Telfer and Wilmore Webley.
Varies from 1 to 3 credits
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: ST-Carcinogenesis
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Animal Science
697C
UMass Amherst
Changes in the prevalence of cancer and contemporary diagnostics and treatments. While these have dramatically decreased mortality, cancer continues to claim more than 585,000 lives annually. The focus will be on the mechanisms that are corrupted in cancer cells and the differences in vulnerability among tissues, the technologies used to define pathways and lessons learned and strategies being used to exploit the vulnerabilities of tumors for personalized and targeted therapeutics.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
421
UMass Amherst

The aim is to empower the student with entry level, current knowledge for the reproductive aspects of any modern animal husbandry including functional anatomy, reproductive life cycles, terminology, discussion of breeding management, common causes of infertility, and assisted reproductive technologies.
Open to Animal Science seniors only. Pre Req: ANIMLSCI 220  This lecture is combined with AnSci 521 Reproduction

This course is open to BS-Animal Science & BS-Pre-Veterinary Science majors only.   The first meeting will be held in 427R Integrated Science Bldg. If you cannot register, contact newth@vasci.umass.edu to be added to this class.

Successful student participants earn a certificate of completion.
This course is open to Senior and Junior Animal Science & Pre-Veterinary Science majors only.   Course is offered over spring break. There is a $300 travel fee. Please contact John Balise at jbalise@vasci.umass.edu to enroll.

attributes.Title: ST-Dairy Calf Mgmt (Fall)
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Animal Science
297DC
UMass Amherst
This course partners the Department of Veterinary and Animal Sciences with a local dairy farm to provide an animal-intensive learning experience. Small groups (2-4) of participating students working in shifts, are expected to feed and care for dairy calves seven days per week under the direct supervision of the instructor. Students are also expected to meet weekly as a group to weigh, clean, and perform other management procedures that may be necessary. Additionally, students will be expected to review and discuss recent research in the area of neonatal management, nutrition, housing, well-being, and health of calves birth to weaning. Instructor consent required.
This course is open to BS-Animal Science & BS-Pre-Veterinary Science majors only.   Students must have some dairy experience and transportation or access to same to enroll, must also complete UMass EH&S training within 2 weeks of class start date. Students must be committed & understand responsibility of course to be eligible to enroll.
Permission is required for interchange registration during all registration periods.

attributes.Title: Good Intentions
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Animal Science
494GI
UMass Amherst
The course focuses on understanding and solving problems that have arisen, at least in part, from human-animal interactions. While these interactions frequently originate with the best of intentions, the consequences are often unexpected and not very good. Through reading primary peer-reviewed literature as well as web postings, students will acquire the specific knowledge, which, combined with information from their previous courses in their major and general education classes, will form the basis for group and class discussions. Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BS-AnSci and BS-PreVet majors.
This class is open to Seniors whose Primary majors are in Animal Science or Pre-Veterinary Science only.

The class is directly supervised by the shepherd with involvement from the staff veterinarian. 260

attributes.Title: Intro Biotechnology Laboratory
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Microbiology
385
UMass Amherst
An introduction to the methodology fundamental to the practice of modern agricultural biotechnology. Techniques covered include establishment and manipulation of plant and animal cell cultures, preparation and analysis of DNA and RNA, production of recombinant protein expression vectors, isolation and characterization of proteins, and use of immunoassays. Major emphasis on the student's performance of laboratory exercises which provide direct experience with each of the techniques mentioned. Prerequisites: BIOLOGY 101 and CHEM 112, or Consent of Instructor.
UG MICROBIO 312 w/ B-  Additional fees are associated with this section.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
63707
64623
Requisite: An introduction to the methodology fundamental to the practice of modern agricultural biotechnology. Techniques covered include establishment and manipulation of plant and animal cell cultures, preparation and analysis of DNA and RNA, production of recombinant protein expression vectors, isolation and characterization of proteins, and use of immunoassays. Major emphasis on the student's performance of laboratory exercises which provide direct experience with each of the techniques mentioned. Prerequisites: BIOLOGY 101 and CHEM 112, or Consent of Instructor.

2016
Animal Science

This course will include labs/hands-on experience; protocol completion and peer reviews; in-depth rodent strains and characteristics, breeding schemes, environmental enrichments and identification methods; humane care, handling, and management of primates, frogs, and fish used in research; routine techniques and practices for each species used in the labs.
